Answer: ASSISTANT:
response:
<<<api>>>: String.getBytes
<<<code>>>: 
try { byte[] b = string.getBytes(Charset.forName("UTF-8")); } catch (Exception e) { e.printStackTrace(); }
<<<explanation>>>: The object your method decompressGZIP() needs is a byte[].

So, the solution to convert a Java String to a byte[] is to use the String.getBytes() method and specify the desired character set, such as "UTF-8". Here's an example:

public class Converter {
public static void main(String[] args) throws UnsupportedEncodingException {
Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);
System.out.println("Enter word:");
String text = scan.nextLine();
byte[] array = text.getBytes(Charset.forName("UTF-8"));
String newStr = array.toString();
System.out.println("Representation in Byte:     " + array);
System.out.println("Byte to String:     " + newStr);
```scss
    byte [] newByte = newStr.getBytes();
    System.out.println("New Byte" + newByte);
    String str2 = new String(newByte, "UTF-8");
    System.out.println(str2);
}
```

}
